folder: Arthur Kill Road & Winant Avenue, Staten Island, NY
original_title: Richmond: Arthur Kill Road - Winant Avenue
text:
2571 Arthur Kill Road, north side, at the head of Winant Avenue, showing the Golder House, seen across part of Rossville Cemetery. The maps of 1874 and 1898 show the house to have been owned by Dr. R. H. Golder.

March 16, 1925

By Wm. T. Davis through P. L. Sperr

(2)
A front view of the Golder House, across Arthur Kil1 Road.

April 30, 1929

P. L. Sperr

folder: Arthur Kill Road & Winant Place, Staten Island, NY
original_title: Richmond: Arthur Kill Road - Winant Place
text:
Arthur Kill Road, east side, at Winant Place, showing the Charleston Station of the United States Post Office.
September 23, 1927
P. L. Sperr

folder: Winant Place & Arthur Kill Road, Staten Island, NY
original_title: Richmond: Winant Place - Arthur Kill Road
text:
Winant Place, adjoining the N. E. corner of Arthur Kill Road (Charleston), showing St. Peter's Evangelical
Lutheran Church.
September 23, 1927
P. L. Sperr

folder: Arthur Kill Road & Winant Avenue, Staten Island, NY
original_title: Richmond: Arthur Kill Road - Winant Avenue
text:
2556 (right) and 2546 Arthur Kill Road, at, and adjoining the S.E. corner of Winant Avenue. The corner house is the Schlmeyer store.
April 30, 1929
P. L. Sperr

folder: Arthur Kill Road & Winant Avenue, Staten Island, NY
original_title: Richmond: Arthur Kill Road - Winant Avenue
text:
2591 Arthur Kill Road, north side, adjoining (to the west) Winant Avenue. This house belonged to D. C. La Forge (1898) and earlier (1874) to C. Cole. Dates refer to maps on which the owners' names appear.
April 30, 1929
P. L. Sperr

folder: Arthur Kill Road & Winant Avenue, Staten Island, NY
original_title: Richmond: Arthur Kill Road - Winant Avenue
text:
Arthur Kill Road, north side, at the head of Winant Avenue, showing the Mary Cole house. It stands about 175 yards back of the road (in rear of No. 2571) near the shore of Arthur Kill.
April 30, 1929
P. L. Sperr
(2)
Part of the Cole property, viewing toward
Arthur Kill.
April 30, 1929
P. L. Sperr
